data.name: Node.js
content: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine that allows for server-side development.
I use Node.js daily in my work as a backend developer. It's my most used technology, enabling me to build scalable, fast applications, and work with APIs, databases, and real-time applications.

Node.js's asynchronous nature and its vast ecosystem of modules (like Express.js, Socket.io, and Mongoose) allow me to build projects efficiently. I've used Node.js for everything from microservices to RESTful APIs and GraphQL services.
In terms of performance, Node.js’s event-driven architecture lets me handle high concurrency efficiently without the need for heavy threads or processes.

data.name: TypeScript
content: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static typing to the language, making it easier to write robust and maintainable code.

I use TypeScript every day in my work, especially with Node.js and NestJS. TypeScript helps me catch errors at compile-time, rather than at runtime, and provides strong type inference that enhances code readability and maintainability.

With TypeScript, I can use interfaces, generics, and enums to structure my code better, making it easier to scale large applications. It is especially useful in backend development with frameworks like NestJS to enforce modular architecture and dependency injection.
TypeScript integrates seamlessly with modern JavaScript tools and frameworks, allowing me to work more productively and write more consistent and reliable code across various projects.

data.name: NestJS
content: NestJS is a progressive Node.js framework built on top of Express, designed for building scalable and maintainable server-side applications using TypeScript.

I use NestJS regularly in projects for clients, leveraging its modular architecture and dependency injection to build robust back-end systems. It aligns well with enterprise-level applications due to its focus on scalability and testability.

NestJS provides a structured environment that allows me to use TypeScript and implement design patterns such as controllers, services, and middleware efficiently. Its strong integration with tools like GraphQL and TypeORM makes it ideal for building API-driven applications.

In client projects, I often utilize NestJS for building microservices, setting up REST APIs, and managing complex workflows. Its out-of-the-box support for testing and validation ensures that applications are not only scalable but also reliable.

data.name: Next.js
content: Next.js is a React framework that allows for server-side rendering and static site generation, making it ideal for building fast and scalable web applications.

While my main expertise lies in back-end development, I have also invested time in learning front-end technologies, with a particular focus on Next.js. It bridges the gap between back-end logic and front-end presentation, allowing me to build full-stack applications.

I appreciate how Next.js integrates features like API routes and SSR (server-side rendering), which align well with my back-end experience. It gives me the flexibility to work on both the client-side and server-side of applications, making it easier to implement end-to-end solutions.

Although front-end development is not my primary focus, I enjoy using Next.js in my free time to expand my skills and create seamless user experiences that connect well with the back-end systems I typically manage.

data.name: Kubernetes
content: Kubernetes, often abbreviated as K8s, is an open-source platform for automating deployment, scaling, and managing containerized applications.

I work with Kubernetes clusters regularly to manage containerized services and ensure applications are scalable and resilient. By using Kubernetes, I can easily deploy and manage microservices in distributed systems.

Kubernetes makes it easier to scale applications across multiple environments, whether on-premise or in the cloud. With helm charts and CI/CD pipelines, I automate the deployment of my services, ensuring smooth and efficient delivery.

data.name: CI/CD
content: CI/CD, which stands for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment, is a crucial process in modern software development. It allows for automated testing, building, and deployment of code.

As a backend developer, I use CI/CD pipelines every day to deploy services efficiently. By automating the testing and deployment processes, I ensure that updates to applications are stable and reliable, while minimizing manual intervention.

I work with tools like GitLab CI, GitHub Actions, and Jenkins to configure pipelines that handle tasks such as linting, unit testing, integration testing, and automatic deployments to various environments.

data.name: Git
content: Git is a distributed version control system that allows teams to track changes, collaborate, and manage code efficiently. It's an essential tool in modern software development.

I use Git every day in my work, managing repositories, branches, and collaborating with teammates. It helps me maintain code integrity and keep track of changes across multiple environments and services.

Git’s features like branching, merging, and rebasing allow me to manage project timelines and work on different features simultaneously without disrupting the main codebase. Tools like GitHub and GitLab are integral to my workflow for pull requests and code reviews.
By using Git, I can ensure that code is versioned correctly, conflicts are resolved efficiently, and my team stays in sync, which is critical for maintaining a seamless development cycle.

data.name: Python
content: Python is a high-level, interpreted language known for its readability and simplicity. It's often compared to pseudocode because of its clean and concise syntax.

Although I don't use Python in my day-to-day job, I frequently turn to it for solving algorithmic challenges and performing basic data science tasks. Its extensive libraries like NumPy and Pandas make it a great tool for data manipulation and analysis.

I enjoy Python because it allows me to focus on solving problems without being bogged down by complex syntax. Its flexibility and wide community support make it ideal for quick prototyping and solving algorithmic problems efficiently.
For me, Python feels almost like writing pseudocode, which is one of the reasons I find it so approachable and fun to work with.

data.name: Java
content: Java is a class-based, object-oriented programming language designed to have fewer implementation dependencies. It is known for its write once, run anywhere philosophy.

During my university studies, Java was my main technology, and I gained extensive familiarity with core OOP principles such as polymorphism and encapsulation. I enjoy working with object-oriented programming because it promotes modularity and code reusability.

Java's strong type system and features like inheritance and interfaces helped me build robust, maintainable applications. I used it frequently to work on multithreading, data structures, and algorithmic problems during my academic years.
Although I primarily work with other technologies now, Java remains a solid foundation in my understanding of software engineering concepts and OOP principles.

data.name: Go
content: Go is a programming language mainly used for backend development. It is fast, simple, powerful and fun.

For some programmers, its simplicity can also be its downfall as it does not have all the bells and whistles as some languages, such as JavaScript. On the other hand, it is much less bloated and gives a lot of freedom to the programmer, very much like its big brother C.

It is fast because it is compiled to machine code. It is powerful because it is statically typed and concurrent. It is simple because it is opinionated, has a very complete standard library and only contains 25 keywords.
I have been using Go for about 3 months and so far I like it very much

data.name: C++
content: C++ is a programming language that builds upon C by adding features such as object-oriented programming, templates, and polymorphism.
It was developed in the 1980s by Bjarne Stroustrup and is still widely used today in operating systems, game engines, embedded systems, and high-performance applications.

C++ is fast because it is compiled to machine code, and it is flexible because it supports both low-level memory management and high-level abstractions. This makes it suitable for performance-critical applications as well as complex software architecture.
One of the key strengths of C++ is its standard template library (STL), which provides ready-to-use data structures and algorithms that greatly speed up development.
C++ is more complex than many modern languages, which can make it difficult to learn, but it provides an unparalleled level of control over system resources and performance.
I have been using C++ since 2015, and I often rely on it for performance-critical applications and embedded systems development.
C++ was my 1st language to learn so it hold sentimental value in my heart.

data.name: HTML
content: HTML is the corner stone of the world wide web. It is used to organize and categorize the content of a website.
I have used HTML to build static websites, dynamic websites, responsive websites, multi-platform software, progressive web apps and native mobile apps.

data.name: CSS
content: CSS is the paint of the world wide web. It is used to style and decorate the content of a website.
Although I have been using CSS for as long as I have been using HTML, I am not as familiar with it.

data.name: JavaScript
content: JavaScript is the cogs of the world wide web. It is used to power the content of a website and make things interactive.

I have been using JavaScript for nearly 5 years and I am very familiar with it. I have used it to build all kinds of solutions, from websites to mobile apps, even desktop applications like video games.
There is a joke about JavaScript that goes like this: JavaScript is so fast that it can render a progress bar in 1 second.

People who tend to like JavaScript usually end up trying to write everything in JavaScript. This is called JavaScript fatigue. I personally prefer to use the right tool for the right job and tend to use JavaScript when time is of the essence and I want to quickly iterate over a piece of software. It's excellent for prototyping and rapid development.

data.name: Machine Learning (ML)
content: Machine Learning is an exciting field where algorithms learn from data to make predictions or decisions. I have a basic understanding of ML models, including concepts like supervised learning and unsupervised learning, as well as common models like linear regression and decision trees.

While I haven't explored this field further, I’m familiar with the foundational principles and how they are applied in real-world scenarios. However, I haven't yet dived deep into implementing complex models like neural networks or deep learning.
For now, my focus remains on understanding the basics and how ML models fit into broader data science and algorithmic challenges.

data.name: Agile
content: Agile is a project management methodology focused on flexibility, collaboration, and continuous improvement.
It is particularly effective in software development where requirements and solutions evolve through the collaborative effort of self-organizing and cross-functional teams.
I primarily use Agile to break down complex projects into smaller, manageable sprints that focus on incremental progress and quick feedback loops.
Each sprint results in a working product increment, ensuring that the team can quickly adapt to changes in requirements or feedback from stakeholders.
